pros: Gained lab benchwork skills and certifications

job_title: Support Desk Assistant in Olympia, WA
pros:
- Clear Team Structure
- Learned a lot on the job
- Relaxed student job 

I worked in the Academic Computing Center as a tech support and absolutely loved my job. We had an internal team wiki where we could write help desk documentation when there weren't many people circulating through the computer lab. This was my first exposure to the tech industry and it taught me how a well-organized, centralized team information architecture can make the world of difference for a job. Of course my experience is limited to this particular niche and I can't speak to the larger issues on campus. But the help desk position I had was the perfect student job in many ways.
cons:
- Low paycheck
- Sometimes there's a smug, virtue-signaling culture (why study ethnography if you think there's only way to think about everything? I'm looking at you, call-out-culture activists)

The only bad interactions I had were with a few students, maybe fresh out of a social-justice related seminar, who were ready to evangelize against the evils of colonialism to anyone who'd listen. Love the passion and the energy—but when you're trying to troubleshoot a DNS connection failure, maybe it's not the best time to bring up your thoughts on how capitalism enslaves us all.  Sometimes interpersonal intelligence is undervalued to theoretical intelligence.

review_title: I like it here a lot much of the time, but the organization has some significant issues.
pros: Most colleagues and people higher up in the hierarchy do a good job, have a sense of personal integrity and treat me with respect; I have a lot of autonomy; most days, I like a lot of what I do; and I think our college, for the most part, does a good job of educating a majority of students.
cons:
(1) Some faculty do poor quality work and we don't seem to be able to get rid of them, which is extremely frustrating. I think their poor work, coupled with enough students that want to skate by and rules that don't prevent skating by by either students or faculty, has devalued the Evergreen education and degree. 

(2) Some really important stuff does not get done: sometimes it's unclear who is really in charge (the hierarchy is pretty flat and the faculty have a lot of power) and sometimes there are rules which seem anti-quality and anti-common sense to me.

(3) Enrollment is down and state support is going down down down and we seem to have to justify our existence more and more every year. I fear that we're going to go down unless our quality goes up and we can find a way to get more funds and/or fund ourselves (becoming more attractive to more out-of-state students, for example).

pros: It's progressive. It's awesome. It's fantastic
cons: There is really not much bad I can say about this company

pros: It does pay a paycheck
cons: Unorganized, out of control, vindictive, back-stabbing.

review_title: Exciting liberal arts teaching, great students and colleagues, difficult times
job_title: Associate Professor Equivalent in Olympia, WA
pros: The students, the students, the students! I have never had such genuine intellectual relationships with my students, thanks to the self-selecting crowd both at Evergreen generally and in the absence of distribution requirements particularly. Also so many excellent colleagues.
cons: In times of crisis, lots of confusion at the administrative level, in part because of the lack of departments, which is also what makes some of the best things at the school possible.  Under any real pressure, it feels like they don't have a way to focus their attention, make decisions that preserve our core values, and make good faculty  choices aimed at supporting our central commitments rather than content coverage.

pros: Working at TESC is an amazing opportunity to further your education in both an academic  and employment related ways. Staff have countless opportunities to attend career building workshops and attend a variety of seminars and certification processes. Senior staff is incredibly intelligent and close to always willing to listen to your concerns.
cons: The only problem about working at evergreen is that it is significantly out of the way from what masks itself as civilization.

pros: Focus on intersectionality, interest in process improvement, discussion and attempted implementation of restorative justice. Relatively relaxed environment, willing to make reasonable adjustments.
cons: Not enough support in regards to a work/life balance, much higher work load for RAs in comparison with other universities with no higher compensation. Not a strong enough channel in place to handle complaints or issues with direct oversight.

job_title: Support Technician II in Olympia, WA
pros:
A very easy-going atmosphere with a lot of free time to do homework.

David is an excellent resource for staff that want to learn data science, information architecture, or system administration.
cons:
Some of the staff have a noted lack of professionalism I found myself having to police my coworkers at time to prevent them from disturbing students.

Items would often disappear such as headphones and kitchen appliances.

A sometimes raucous atmosphere.

pros:
There are some very good groups of people to work with there.
Working on a college campus with an on site gym and pool. Lots of smart people there (it's a college...)
Evergreen has an informal culture, and this can translate into a lot of flexibility in your job.
cons:
Pay may be mediocre compared to private industry.
The informal atmosphere at times translates into a very disorganized work environment with no clear lines of authority. This means it can be difficult to get decisions made.

review_title: Nice work if you can get it (student employment). A great place with a variety of opportunities for student employees.
pros: Flexible work schedule, diversity of options, work relevant to your academic major, congenial atmosphere with other student employees, access to interesting equipment/technologies, ability to implement your own ideas on certain programs.
cons: Wages for student employees (even highly skilled ones like lab workers or language tutors) remain low due to budget constraints, you will be paid for a maximum of 19 hours per week even if you work over those hours.

pros: Lots of great people, cool things happening and cultural hub for Olympia. Beautiful campus and lovely place to work. State benefits are hard to beat.
cons: It's a state job so it comes with all the politics and people that come with that. Some folks work really hard but others hardly work and quality of coworkers can vary wildly depending on what department you work within. Academic groups are generally good while administrative departments can be frustrating places to work.

review_title: A good place to work if you're just starting a career
pros: Very flexible when it comes to scheduling. Most of the other staff members are very friendly. Many opportunities to learn and apply new skills.
cons: Very few opportunities for advancement. EverGreen also doesn't offer much in benefits. There can be a lot of drama in the workplace at times.

pros: As a student employee, the hours were flexible and it was a convenient place to work. All the people I worked with at the admissions office were great.
cons: 19 hours per week is the max you can work, and I was only able to get about 6 hours per week at the most. Most on-campus jobs are minimum wage or only slightly above that.

pros: Great school with passionate students who really want to be there. Invigorating environment for faculty--lots of opportunity to continual learn and grow. Benefits for half-time work.
cons: Part time employees are second-class citizens-don't have the same access to opportunities as full time people.

job_title: Web and Print Assistant in Newberg, OR

cons: Some times the work is really repetitive. The pace can get slow and you have to hunt for stuff to do.

pros: It comes with flexible hours, and the work environment is fantastic. I worked in the theatre and enjoyed it tremendously. My boss especially was fantastic.
cons: Because of work study status, there was a limit to the amount that could be worked. And, like many large state agencies, there was a certain amount of bureaucratic nonsense.
